title: Which book is good for medieval India history Mains? - Quora

response.answer_text: Medieval India is a tale of diversities,in fact history is synonymous with continuity and to analyse and explain the convulsions of time is one of its various specialities. The interregnum between the death of Harsha in the mid-seventh century( 648AD) and the rise of the Delhi Sultanate nearly six hundred years later is often viewed as a tedious epoch in Indian History, it is accepted that there is a period of overlap during which one phase blends into the other. This interim period is now called “early medieval India”, with the medieval period, properly speaking, regarded as beginning with the establishment of Turkish rule in a Delhi in 1206AD. The currents of feudalism from within and establishment of a new ruling class from without, became propellants, instigating momentous changes in Indian history at social,economic, and cultural levels. The native people came to terms with the Muslim social setup in the form of a ruling class, and this ruling class got opportunity to interact and gradually evolved into a composite culture. Before embarking upon a study of medieval Indian history, it is pertinent to understand the following essentials: Medieval period should not be read in isolation from other periods, understand the society of the time ( say 8th C A.D) where there was no big empire, north India splintered into small states with differences and rivalry, no nationalism existed and very reason why Mahmud of Ghaznavi invaded leading up to invasion of Mohammed of Ghori. Political maximisation post-Delhi Sultanate by the establishment of centralised Mughal empire.Contribution of Islam and conversion to Islam, the aura created by Sufi saints in creating a just society without casteism, discrimination. Is is for this reason that reformist current ensued in medieval times leading to Bhakti movement, Sufism, Sikhism evolution and many other social and cultural revolution.the decline of Great Mughals and the subsequent emergence of powerful regional states. And the historical lull, few call this as the Dark age! Find out why there is so much controversy there.. then the arrival of British power.It is needless to say , rather than concentrating on genealogical history of who rule at what time period, it would be fruitful to dig deep an established the undercurrent of socio-cultural aspects leading to politics of the day and the important role played by religion to establish and dominate the medieval times.Some LIGHT BOOKS to start up: NCERT books - an indispensable first book to beginSatish Chandra - Medieval India part I ,IISunil Kumar - The emergence of Delhi SultanateP. Spear - The History of India.J.F. Richards - The Mughal EmpireIrfan Habib - Essays in Indian history: Towards a Marxist perceptionIrfan Habib - the agrarian system of Mughal India.—————— the Cambridge economic history of India. Vol- IA.L. Srivastava - The Mughal empire 1526–1803R.P. Tripathi - Rise and Fall of the Mughal EmpireDouglas Streausand - The formation of the Mughal Empire.M.N. Pearson - Shivaji and the decline of the Mughal empire.Burton Stein - Peasant state and society in medieval south India.On specific themes (advanced studies):- Athar Ali - The apparatus of empire: awards of ranks, offices and titles to Mughal nobility.Encyclopaedia of Islam eds. B. LewisIrfan Habib - an atlas of the Mughal empire: political and economic maps with detailed notes,bibliography, and index.Ahmad Aziz - Studies in Islamic cultures in the Indian environment.Jadunath Sarkar - History of Aurangzeb 5vols.A.L. Srivastava - Akbar the great, 3 Vols.Ebba Koch - Mughal architecture: An outline of its history and development.R. Barnett - North India between two empires, Awadh, the Mughals and British.Eliot and Dawson - History of India as told by its own historians . 8vols.The sources on medieval India are primary(mostly Persian ) in form of aids on literature, guides to original manuscripts and periodical Monographic literature, secondary in form of research papers and books are vast, the above listings is thus far from comprehensive. For an exhaustive bibliography look into the each books mentioned above u can get further info on various others books and text from it. Happy ride and enjoy India as told by historians ..

Medieval India: From Sultanat to the Mughals-Delhi Sultanat (1206-1526) - 1 ( by satish Chandra) Medieval India: From Sultanat To The Mughals-Delhi Sultanat (1206-1526) - 1 explores the period from 1206 to 1526, in India and talks about the rulers of the time. It is a critique of the social, economic, and political condition of the people, from the medieval period of Indian history. Like all big things that come in small packages, this one has gems of important information adorned in simple English that is suitable for a wide audience. The contents of the book describe the conditions in central and west Asia, and the Rajput Kingdom in the 10th century, and Delhi Sultanat. It also talks about topics like Internal Conflicts, Mongol Threats, Rebellions, the Bahamani Kingdom, advent of the Portuguese, Gujarat Malwa, and all the activity till 1526. Medieval India: From Sultanat To The Mughals-Delhi Sultanat (1206-1526) - 1 is a compilation of detailed research, into the times before the Mughal rule in India. It chronicles the various aspects of the times, and aims to analyse it for a better understanding of the foundation of the Mughal rule and what actually led to it. The book, apart from helping a student grasp a general understanding of the times, is recommended for an individual pursuing graduate studies in history. It is also useful for an IAS aspirant. Published by Har Anand Publications in 2007, the book is available in paperback. Medieval India: From Sultanat to the Mughals- Mughal Empire (1526-1748) - 2 Medieval India: From Sultanat To The Mughals- Mughal Empire (1526-1748) - 2 by Satish Chandra can be regarded as an authentic and comprehensive account of India's medieval history. Holistically covering the historical aspects, from the period of the Delhi sultanate to that of the Mughal empire, the book rightly throws light into the social, cultural, architectural, political, religious, and economic patterns of medieval India. The book is best known for its detailed accounts on the various dynasties, their political and cultural ideologies, and the pattern of governance. What makes the Medieval India: From Sultanat To The Mughals- Mughal Empire (1526-1748) - 2 distinct from other historic books, is the simple and engaging pattern that the author has followed throughout the book. With insights on the cultural legacy left by the dynasties, the book can also be a source to gather information about India's rich tradition and culture. The period of rulers from the Mamluk dynasty, Khilji dynasty, Tughlaq dynasty, Sayyid dynasty, and Lodi dynasty are comprehensively covered in the book. The book also explains the historical events that led to the foundation of the Mughal empire in India. Referring to the Indian cultural renaissance, the author has included detailed chapters on arts, music, and literature specific to each period. The monetary system followed in each dynasty is also explained, to denote the economic patterns. The book has extensive sections on Mughal architecture, governance, and religious practices. The battle of Panipat and the subsequent siege of Delhi is illustrated beautifully by the author. Published in 2007 by Har Anand Publications, the book is available in paperback.
